fr:title.text: Simple colinks in the category of sets

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Simple colinks in the category of sets

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let X, X', Y, Y' be sets. A simple colink f : \binom {X'}{X} \to \binom {Y'}{Y} is given by:

html:ul.html:li: A function f : X \to Y called the forwards pass
A function f' : X \times Y' \to X' called the backwards pass

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Simple colinks are so-called to distinguish them from indexed colinks, which also exist in the category of sets.

Given simple colinks f : \binom {X'}{X} \to \binom {Y'}{Y} and g : \binom {Y'}{Y} \to \binom {Z'}{Z}, there is a compsite colink fg : \binom {X'}{X} \to \binom {Z'}{Z} whose forwards pass is the composite function (fg) (x) = g (f (x)) and whose backwards pass is the function (fg)' : X \times Z' \to X' defined by the colink composition law
(fg)' (x, z') = f' (x, g' (f (x), z'))

In this case we can directly prove that colink composition is associative as follows:
((fg)h)' (x, w') = (fg)' (x, h' ((fg) (x), w'))
= f' (x, g' (f (x), h' (g (f (x)), w')))
= f' (x, (gh)' (f (x), w')) = (f(gh))' (x, w')

Since the category of sets is cartesian closed, the category of colinks in the category of sets can be constructed either as a category of colinks in a category with finite products or as a category of colinks in a monoidal closed category.

fr:title.text: Colinks in a category with finite products

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Colinks in a category with finite products

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal C be a category with finite products, and let X, X', Y, Y' be objects of \mathcal C. A colink f : \binom {X'}{X} \to \binom {Y'}{Y} is given by:

html:ul.html:li: A morphism f : X \to Y called the forwards pass
A morphism f' : X \times Y' \to X' called the backwards pass

fr:mainmatter.html:p:
Given colinks f : \binom {X'}{X} \to \binom {Y'}{Y} and g : \binom {Y'}{Y} \to \binom {Z'}{Z}, there is a composite colink fg : \binom {X'}{X} \to \binom {Z'}{Z} whose forwards pass is the composite morphism fg : X \to Z and whose backwards pass (fg)' is the composite
X \times Z' \overset {\Delta _X \times Z'}\longrightarrow X \times X \times Z' \overset {X \times f \times Z'}\longrightarrow X \times Y \times Z' \overset {X \times g'}\longrightarrow X \times Y' \overset {f'}\longrightarrow X'
It is not obvious from this definition that colink composition is associative. A direct proof is possible but tedious, so we prefer to prove it using machinery of fibred categories.
For a category \mathcal C with finite products, there is a category \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal L} (\mathcal C) where:

html:ul.html:li: Objects of \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal L} (\mathcal C) are pairs of objects of \mathcal C, written \binom {X'}{X}
Morphisms \binom {X'}{X} \to \binom {Y'}{Y} of \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal L} (\mathcal C) are colinks \binom {X'}{X} \to \binom {Y'}{Y} in \mathcal C
The identity morphism \binom {X'}{X} \to \binom {X'}{X} has as forwards pass the identity morphism X \to X in \mathcal C, and as backwards pass the projection X \times X' \to X'
Composite morphisms are given by colink composition

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Colinks, usually called lenses, are pairs of morphisms with the backwards morphism also having an input in the forwards direction. Composition of colinks is an abstraction of the chain rule of calculus.

There are many definitions of colinks that apply with different assumptions on the base category. In each of these cases, for a category \mathcal C with the appropriate structure we will obtain a category \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal L} (\mathcal C) whose morphisms are colinks in \mathcal C.

fr:title.text: From actegories to locally graded categories

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: From actegories to locally graded categories

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal E be a monoidal category and \mathcal C an \mathcal E-actegory. We construct a locally graded category called \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal P}_\mathcal E (\mathcal C), which we regard as a Para construction, as follows:

html:ul.html:li: The objects of \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal P}_\mathcal E (\mathcal C) are objects of \mathcal C

For objects X, Y of \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal P}_\mathcal E (\mathcal C), the hom-object \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal P}_\mathcal E (\mathcal C) (X, Y) : \mathcal E^\mathrm {op} \to \mathbf {Set} is given by \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal P}_\mathcal E (\mathcal C)_M (X, Y) = \mathcal C (X \bullet M, Y)
The identity morphism in \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal P}_\mathcal E (\mathcal C)_I (X, X) is given by the unitor X \bullet I \to X

The composition of f : \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal P}_\mathcal E (\mathcal C)_{M_1} (X, Y) and g : \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal P}_\mathcal E (\mathcal C)_{M_2} (Y, Z) is fg : \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal P}_\mathcal E (\mathcal C)_{M_1 \otimes M_2} (X, Z) given by X \bullet (M_1 \otimes M_2) \to (X \bullet M_1) \bullet M_2 \to Y \bullet M_2 \to Z

fr:title.text: The golden theorem of actegories

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal E be a symmetric monoidal category. Every \mathcal E-actegory that is also a symmetric monoidal category in a compatible way is necessarily defined by a strong symmetric monoidal functor \mathcal E \to \mathcal C, up to natural isomorphism.

Specifically, if \bullet : \mathcal C \times \mathcal E \to \mathcal C is a symmetric monoidal actegory then X \bullet M \cong X \otimes F (M) where F : \mathcal E \to \mathcal C is defined by F (M) = I \bullet M.
This means that in the vast majority of cases, actegories are redundant and strong symmetric monoidal functors suffice.
Reference: Actegories for the working amthematician, section 5

fr:title.text: Locally graded categories

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal E be a monoidal category. A category locally graded in \mathcal E is a category enriched in the monoidal category of presheaves [\mathcal E^\mathrm {op}, \mathbf {Set}] with Day convolution.
Unwinding the definition, a category \mathcal C locally graded in \mathcal E is given by the following data:

html:ul.html:li: A class of objects
For each pair of objects X, Y of \mathcal C and each object M of \mathcal E, a set of morphisms #\mathcal C (X, Y) (M), which we also write \mathcal C_M (X, Y)
For each object X of \mathcal C, an identity morphism in \mathcal C_I (X, X)
For morphisms f : \mathcal C_{M_1} (X, Y) and g : \mathcal C_{M_2} (Y, Z), a composite morphism fg : \mathcal C_{M_1 \otimes M_2} (X, Z)
Coherence isomorphisms

fr:title.text: Para construction

It is not obvious from this definition that colink composition is associative. A direct proof is possible but tedious, so we prefer to prove it using machinery of fibred categories.
For a category \mathcal C with finite products, there is a category \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal L} (\mathcal C) where:

html:ul.html:li: Objects of \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal L} (\mathcal C) are pairs of objects of \mathcal C, written \binom {X'}{X}
Morphisms \binom {X'}{X} \to \binom {Y'}{Y} of \overset {\leftarrow }{\mathcal L} (\mathcal C) are colinks \binom {X'}{X} \to \binom {Y'}{Y} in \mathcal C
The identity morphism \binom {X'}{X} \to \binom {X'}{X} has as forwards pass the identity morphism X \to X in \mathcal C, and as backwards pass the projection X \times X' \to X'
Composite morphisms are given by colink composition
